Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments, including 1914,0317.10) of Attic black-figured pottery cup of pre-Komast shape; interior: glazed black with two red lines on lip and two red bands at top of wall; exterior: diagonal zig-zags between bands on lip; two friezes in black-figure on bowl; above, much of lion or panther, to left; incised spoked rosette as filling ornament; below, probably part of stag's antler or goat's horn.
Curator's comments: The sherd joins British Museum 1914,0317.10. The cup (classified as Pre- Komast by Brijder 1983) betrays Corinthian influence both in shape and decoration: the convex lip with its stepped decoration on the outside, the existence of a second frieze and the red and reserved lines on the inside. For detailed discussion and comparanda, see Brijder 1983, 63-5, pl. 1a; Williams, D. 'From East and West: the inspiration of Athenian potters', in E. M. Moormann and V. V. Stissi (eds), Shapes and Images. Studies on Attic Black Figure and Related Topics in Honour of Herman A. G. Brijder. Leuven 2009, 1-10, esp. 5 fig. 5.
Bibliographic references: Beazley & Payne 1929 / Attic Black Figured Fragments from Naukratis (no. 20)
Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (p. 197)
Beazley 1944 / Groups of Early Attic Black Figure (p. 46, no. 16) (KX painter)

Brijder 1983 / Siana Cups 1 (p. 63ff, p. 222, no. PK9)
